items.content:

__
Chris Brandrick, Editor

#â€‹608 â€” September 6, 2023 | Read on the web

Astro 3.0 Released â€” This new version of popular web framework / site generation system Astro claims to be amongst the first to support the View Transitions API â€” making transitions possible without rolling out a SPA. This release also includes image optimization improvements, optimized built outputs, andÂ more. Repo here.

Astro

ğŸª Astro was also featured by the Chrome team for their use of the View Transitions API.

Browse Websites by What Fonts They Use â€” If youâ€™re looking for inspiration or the ways in which a particular font has been used, this is a handyÂ resource.

Bertrand Bruandet

Headless CMS with AI Capabilities, Thatâ€™s Kontent.ai â€” Streamline your code and scale with ease using Kontent.ai. Generate TS types from your content model, use CLI for maintenance tasks, and leverage rich text resolvers to map React components easily. And finally, use AI to generate and improveÂ content.

Kontent.ai sponsor

A Review of Browser Video Players â€” Browsers each provide built-in video players for the <video> element. Here, Adrian runs some tests to see how they compare from an accessibility point ofÂ view.

Adrian Roselli

How Layout Position Impacts Three Big Web Performance Levers â€” An interesting performance study from Shopify that looked at three common issues that impact on layout position â€”Â namely lazy loading images above the fold, asynchronous loading of CSS needed for elements above the fold, and not prioritizing the fetch of the the Largest Contentful Paint (LCP) image.

Sia Karamalegos (Shopify)

  • The first public working draft for the CSS Transitions Level 2 spec is nowÂ live.

  • Firefox, as of version 117, now has automatic translation, a laÂ Chrome.

  • In other browser news, Chrome is pushing ahead with its not-exactly-much-loved new way to target ads at users based on their browser history.

  • If you use QR codes anyway, be careful and check where they actually point to.. otherwise you could ğŸ“„ have to recall several physical products (PDF) for containing QR codes pointing to offensive web sites.. ğŸ™ˆ

Maciek Fitzner

Where to Put Focus When Deleting a Thing â€” When deleting something Adrian notes that you should â€œgenerally move focus to the prior equivalent control or its groupingÂ containerâ€.

Adrian Roselli

Sentry sponsor

Hristiyan Dodov

Simon Farshid

Information Architecture vs. Sitemaps: Whatâ€™s the Difference?

Ahmad Shadeed

How to Create a Chrome Extension in 10 Minutes Flat
James Hibbard

Eight Micro Tips for Remarkably Better Typography
Matej Latin

ğŸ” FIVE IN FOCUS with Michelle Barker

Five frontend recommendations from Michelle Barker, Senior Front End Developer at Ada Mode and author of CSS { In Real Life }. She's has a keen interest in digital sustainability and creative coding.

  1. WebPageTest: Carbon Control
    WebPageTest measures your siteâ€™s performance, and has recently added a new feature, Carbon Control, which helps to measure the CO2 impact, along with tips for reducing it.
  2. Lite YouTube Embed
    Embedded videos can be responsible for a lot of performance problems (and CO2 emissions) of a site. This package by Paul Irish ensures they are only loaded upon interaction, providing a better (faster) user experience.
  3. SVG OMG
    Jake Archibaldâ€™s tool for minifying and compressing SVGs is indispensable for any developer working with SVG.
  4. SVG Path Visualizer
    A really cool playground to help you understand how SVG path syntax works.
  5. ENV Switcher for VS Code
    This VS Code extension enables easy switching between different .env files in a project.

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

UI Skeleton Gallery: SVG Loader UI Elements for Design Wireframes & Mockups â€” As explained in the FAQ, â€œA skeleton element is a UI element or screen that doesnâ€™t contain actual content but instead offers a low-fidelity page wireframe before content completelyÂ loads.â€

BrandBird

Feature Flags That Devs Actually Want to Use â€” DevCycle makes it easy to create and manage flags at scale, maintain an organized codebase, and stay on top of techÂ debt.

DevCycle sponsor

tw2panda: An Online Tool and CLI to Migrate Code from Tailwind to Panda CSS â€” Panda is a type-safe CSS-in-JS solution we featured a few months back. You can try the online tool here or install locally to use the CLI. Also offers a VS CodeÂ extension.

Alexandre Stahmer

ğŸ¸Â SVGuitar: Create SVG-Based Guitar Chord Charts â€” You can experiment with it in this liveÂ demo.

Raphael Voellmy

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

Video Thumbnail API: Get Thumbnail Images from Public VideoÂ URLs â€” Enter a public video URL along with a time in seconds to grab a thumbnail at the closest frame. Also usable via a GET request using theÂ API.

Tim Bennetto

SVG Shapes: A Collection of 100+ Customizable SVG Shapes â€” Choose any shape in the gallery then customize the color using a solid fill or gradient of yourÂ choice.

Anup Aglawe

items.title: Here's why you shouldn't make viewport assumptions
items.content:
ğŸ‘‹ Hey! After a week off, we're back with more frontend updates. Let's get to it!
__
Chris Brandrick, Editor

ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹607 â€” August 30, 2023 | Read on the web

The Ideal Viewport Doesnâ€™t Exist â€” In an attempt to answer the question â€œhow fragmented are viewport sizes?â€ a group of developers collated over 120,000 datapoints with over 2,300 unique viewport sizes and has presented it superbly here. The takeaway is that â€œyou simply do not know how users are going to visit your website or web appâ€.

Leanne Renard, Liridon Hasani and Andy Bell

â„¹ï¸ A caveat to be aware of: the data mainly comes from users in the USA andÂ Europe.

Use Web Components for What Theyâ€™re Good At â€” Nolan weighs in on a recent debate around the use of Web Components, highlighting the tradeoffs to consider when usingÂ them.

Nolan Lawson

Join Us at SurrealDB World - The Future Database for Cloud-Native Applications â€” Join SurrealDB World Online on September 13th, 2023 at 10:00 AM BST as we unveil SurrealDB 1.0.0 alongside some exciting announcements that will undoubtedly shape the future of the databaseÂ industry.

SurrealDB sponsor

â­ï¸ The State of CSS 2023 Survey Results â€” Over the past few years not only have we seen an uptick in new CSS features, but weâ€™ve also seen browsers adopting these new capabilities at a much faster pace. As such the key takeaway from this yearâ€™s survey seems to be that usage of CSS frameworks are now on something of a downward slope. As ever, there is a ton of stuff to dig into here â€” a real lay of the land for all thingsÂ CSS.

Devographics

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Support for CSS Nesting is now in Firefox 117, meaning browser support is now widespread. Wes Bos shows us ğŸ¦ how it works in this Twitter/XÂ thread.

  • The handy WebGlossary.info explains over 3,500 web development terms and concepts. One to bookmark.

  • We're seeing more and more of this around the World: Child safety bills are reshaping the internet for everyone.

  • What's the best way to write alt text for code snippet images shared on social? Ben Myers has given it some thought.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

BÃ©zier Curves and the Logic Behind Them â€” A superb dive into the logic behind bÃ©zier curves as used in CSS animations and visual elements. Really well documented, with excellent visualÂ explainers.

Richard EkwonyÃ©

Falling For Oklch: A Love Story of Color Spaces, Gamuts, andÂ CSS â€” An exploration of the Oklch color space and how we can start using it in CSSÂ today.

Geoff Graham (Smashing Magazine)

WebGL Image Processing â€” Explorations of several image processing techniques using GPU shaders in the browser, covering color correction, blend modes, dithering, andÂ more.

Maxim McNair

Create a Culture of Code Coverage with Codecov â€” Identify untested code to help you find bugs before they ever get pushed to production. Get startedÂ today.

Codecov by Sentry sponsor

A Few Interesting Ways To Use CSS Shadows (For More ThanÂ Depth) â€” A few experiments with different shadow effects (using two CSS properties and a filter) to make interesting hover effects, different text styles, and even casting shadows on otherÂ shadows.

Preethi Sam

How to Make Next-Level Figma Plugins: Auth, Routing, Storage, and More â€” A look at building full-featured, frontend-app-style Figma plugin, with storage, auth, routing, and more, with tool recommendations and otherÂ tips.

Rita Klubochkina

How to Create Isometric Diagrams using SVG â€” A good introduction to the principles of isometricÂ drawing.
Artur Khokhlov

â–¶Â Â Debugging Interaction to Next Paint
Brian Ramirez

Why Tailwind CSS 'Won'
Matt Rickard

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Image-To-Pixel: An Editor to Convert Photos to Pixel Art â€” Built with p5.js, you can customize the pixelation by choosing a dither amount, dither style, posterize level, and you can even upload your own color palette for the dithering. GitHubÂ repo.

Tezumie

Peaks.js 3.0: View and Interact with Audio Waveforms â€” A JavaScript component for browser-based audio waveform visualization that comes from the BBCâ€™s R&D department. Thereâ€™s a live example on the homepage. GitHubÂ repo.

BBC

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor

Better Select: A Web Component for a Better Select Element â€” Will fallback to a regular select, or optionally a native select on mobile devices, and has keyboard support. Try some demos here.

Smart Impact IT

SnippetBuilder: Create Pretty Screenshots of Code â€” This kind of tool isnâ€™t unique but this one has some unique features, like the ability to add multiple â€œeditorsâ€ to the screenshot, drag and drop tech logos, and a variety of pre-made gradients for theÂ background.

Sachin Chaurasiya

ğŸ’¡ Chalk.ist is another code-to-image tool we particularlyÂ like.

Default Composer: Tiny JavaScript Utility to Set Default Values for Nested Objects â€” It will replace empty strings, arrays, objects, and null/undefined, with default values that you set, to simplify the process of filling empty slots in various objects in yourÂ code.

Aral Roca Gomez

Toools.design: An Archive of 1000+ Design Resources â€” A well presented directory divided into 18 categories (icons, typography, stock photos, design tools, podcasts, etc.), where you can find a variety of products, tools andÂ resources.

Pascal Strasche

items.content:
ğŸï¸ In an attempt to see some sunshine, the newsletter is taking a break next week â€”Â I'll be back in your inbox on Wednesday, August 30. Catch youÂ then!
__
Chris Brandrick, your editor

ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹606 â€” August 16, 2023 | Read on the web

How to Make Lists Accessible â€” This guide covers why accessible lists and tables matter, how to make them accessible, and how to fix inaccessible lists andÂ tables.

Whitney Lewis

Testing Your Refresh Rate with a CSS Trick? â€” This is a fascinating way to show users the refresh rate of their screen by spinning a specially designed zoetrope-like disc graphic at speed. As it spins, the numbers representing the viewerâ€™s refresh rate should remain visually stable unlike surroundingÂ numbers.

Luna on cohost

Bryntum Grid - A Lightning Fast JavaScript DataÂ Grid â€” Try a professional JS data grid component which lets you edit, sort, group and filter datasets with fantastic UX & performance. Includes a TreeGrid, API docs and lots of demos. Seamlessly integrates with React, Angular & VueÂ apps.

Bryntum Grid sponsor

Alt Text Hall of Fame: Celebrating Well-Written Image Descriptions â€” Why is alt text important? This site goes some way to explain via a showcase of goodÂ examples.

Stefan Bohacek

'Itâ€™s Time to End Damaging Website Design Practices That May Harm Your Users' â€” The UKâ€™s Information Commissionerâ€™s Office (ICO) along with the Competition & Markets Authority (CMA) have released a joint paper on harmful design in digital markets. PDFÂ here.

Almond and Hayter

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Here's a look over what's new in the DevTools of Chrome 116, including a visual way to configure linear timings for transitions in the Easing Editor.

  • Could browsers be required by law to stop you from visiting infringing sites?

  • Chris Siebenmann notes how browsers "barely care what HTTP status code your web pages are served with".

  • Chad Stewart is hosting a free workshop next week on architecture and tooling for your next frontend project.

  • Hop in the internet time machine and see what Apple, Google and the Amazon websites looked like in 1999.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Four New CSS Features for Smooth Entry and Exit Animations â€” This is a solid look at new capabilities found in Chrome 116 and 117 that enable smooth animations and transitions for discrete properties. Lots of good visuals and codeÂ examples.

Kravets and Arhar (Chrome Developers)

An Overview of CSS Sizing Units â€” Explore the four broad categories of CSS sizing units, how to apply them in your layouts, and how to choose the best ones in eachÂ scenario.

Tiffany Brown

Chrome Extension Maker Tells of Pressure to Sell Out â€” A popular Chrome extension creator has received more than 130 solicitations to monetize their browser tool over the years. â€œAnyone with sizable audience in this surveillance economy is invited to stuff their add-ons with tracking andÂ adsâ€.

Thomas Claburn interview

The Future of Open Source: SaaS, the Final Frontier â€” Software has moved to the cloud â€¦ and open source is moving with it. Join SaaS leaders for the discussion on SeptÂ 7.

Sentry sponsor

A Fancy Hover Effect For Your Avatar â€” A quick look at how to create a neat â€˜pop outâ€™ hover effect usingÂ CSS.

Temani Afif

User-Adaptive Interfaces with AccentColor â€” A quick tip on respecting user preferences for formÂ controls via the new AccentColor keyword.

Ollie Williams

Bringing Sharp to WebAssembly and WebContainers â€” A look at how itâ€™s possible to bring Sharp, a popular Node.js image manipulation module, into the browser. This is futuristicÂ stuff.

Ingvar Stepanyan

â–¶Â Â Drawing a Cute Character with CSS â€” In roughly ten minutes Alvaro shows us how to create an Anime-style character using justÂ CSS. The effort took around an hour and twenty minutes, but we get to watch along via a time-lapse.

Alvaro Montoro

Prepare Your Firefox Desktop Extension for the Upcoming Android Release â€” â€œFirefox will become the only major Android browser to support an open extensionÂ ecosystem.â€

Scott DeVaney (Mozilla)

Introducing the Energy Saving Concept of Lower CarbonÂ Graphics â€” This article is focused specifically on TVs and saving energy based on what colors are shown on screen, but the findings may be of interest to us frontend devs â€” who often make a lot of decisions about what ends up on many a variety ofÂ screen.

Colin Warhurst (BBC)

â–¶Â Â Create Direction-Aware Effects using Modern CSS
Kevin Powell

How to Use the CSS Grid repeat() Function

#â€‹605 â€” August 9, 2023 | Read on the web

A Blog Post with Every HTML Element?Â Almost. â€” Taking 18 months to come together, this post makes a brave attempt to squeeze every HTML element (including some former elements like <marquee> and <blink>) into a single place. Itâ€™s a fantastically retro-feeling reunion that starts off feeling a little dull but rapidly picks up theÂ pace, even if poor <applet> doesn't makeÂ theÂ cut..

Patrick Weaver

Practical CSS Layouts with Jen Kramer â€” Join Jen for this extensive video course and learn to code complex layouts using CSS Grid and Flexbox. The course covers responsive design, handling images, styling, navigation and more via a series ofÂ exercises.

WordPress 6.3 â€œLionelâ€ Released â€” Hailed as a â€œmomentous releaseâ€, the universally popular CMS includes a new Site Editor experience, the ability to create and sync block â€˜patternsâ€™, new design tools, keyboard shortcut changes, style revision tracking, along with performance and accessibilityÂ improvements.

Mary recaps why it matters, how it will hopefully work, and even touches upon the browser politics of the newÂ project.

Mary Branscombe (The New Stack)

Smoothing Out the Scrolling Experience in Chrome on Android â€” A look at how the scrolling experience on Chrome for Android has been improved, reducing slow scrolling jank by 2x. The post shares how the Chromium team discovered and evaluated the problem, and how that helped them â€œdesign a better browser experience goingÂ forwardâ€.

Stephen Nusko (Google)

Optimizing Speed on eBay â€” â€œFor every 100 milliseconds improvement in search page loading time, eBay saw a 0.5% increase in â€˜Add to Cartâ€™ count.â€ â€”Â This perfectly highlights how important performance can be at such huge scale. Addy runs through just how the performance of eBayâ€™s sites and apps were optimized for a faster overall userÂ experience.

Addy Osmani

Addy didn't just stop with looking at eBay, he also took a look at YouTube's efforts to increase their Core Web Vitals pass rates.

Nate Schloesser

Typograms: A Way to Render ASCII Diagrams More Elegantly â€” An intriguing project out of Google that lets you â€˜drawâ€™ diagrams in plain ASCII text within special script tags and these will then be rendered into nicer looking versions in the browser. An interesting approach if Mermaid is too full on for yourÂ needs.

Sam Goto / Google

ğŸ’¡ Monodraw is a neat macOS app for drawing similar ASCII-basedÂ digrams.

svg-drawing: A Simple Canvas to Draw, "Replay", and Export SVG Line Art â€” You can deep link to any drawing, adjust some draw settings, and even change the options for playing back the drawing by animating theÂ lines. Please excuse my shoddy rocket drawing.

catsjuice

OGL 1.0: A Minimal WebGL Framework â€” WebGL is far from the easiest technology to use on its own, so libraries like Three.js are often used to make it more accessible. OGL has a similar motive while sticking closer to the WebGLÂ metal.

Nathan Gordon et al.

Vaul: An Unstyled Drawer Component for React â€” Also referred to as a â€œbottom sheetâ€, useful for mobile interfaces as a replacement for a dialog element and itâ€™s powered by Radix UIâ€™s dialogÂ component.

Mobile FIRST

MyTailwind: Interactively Customize Tailwind Components â€” Gives you a simple visual editor where you can customize styles for about 11 different components (button, navbar, card, sidebar, alert, etc.), then copy the HTML with the TailwindÂ classes.

Ashraful Malik

Maily: An Editor for Creating Beautiful, Pre-Designed, Mobile-Ready Emails
Arik Chakma

ğŸ® ...and finally

noclip â€”Â A Digital Web-Based Museum of Video GameÂ Levels â€” This neat site is a browser-based way to explore levels from a variety of classic games. Iâ€™ve just been exploring the castle grounds of Super Mario 64 and the streets of GTA IIIâ€™s Liberty City. A cool nostalgia trip if nothing else. RepoÂ here. Three cheers forÂ WebGL!
